column4: Original_notes
cultivated until they lose their fertility. When a garden is worn out, a new site has to be chosen
ploughing is recent
hoe cultivation
flails used
recently

Fish-skin ashes to cure disease, not specifically to fertilize (Krige 1936: 195); contra fertilization (Tyler 1891: 46, 111); Zulu method for manuring is primitive, planting on the site of an old kraal (Gibson 1903: 243)
no mention of these traits
no mention of these traits
no mention of these traits
no mention of these traits

All land belongs to the king, as representative of nation (Krige 1935: 176); king allots land; Native custom does not recognize private property in the soil (Krige 1936: 189); Land is national prop. (Farrer 1879: 97)
Pleiades signal planting season; “doctor” of the king would send to tell him that the time had arrived; (king must plant first)
not mentioned
there is permanent storage; a lot of gift-giving to the king who does not produce anything (Krige 1936: 202f.); (corn not immed. used)
grain stored in underground pits; (king gets beer rather than grain); stocked by [crossed out]
bullocks trained to carry burdens on their heads
recent
(-); Some kraals had cattle of all one color (Krige 1936: 187); appearance definitely manipulated after birth
all youths
no data available; kraal moved because of a bad dream. During war time – implies poor defense (Tyler 1891: 108); move kraal due to death etc. (Krige 1936: 53)
(-); no data available; The kraal could last as long as the head (Bryant 1965: 42 for idea)
regular [underlined]; circular arrangement around the kraal (Krige 1936: 42-44); circular kraal arrang. (Gibson 1903: 2)
permanent [striked out]; 500 huts
permanent [striked out]; 500 huts (Leslie 1875: 82); barracks: 500-2000 men (Bryant 1965: 78)
kraal (called village) w/ 500 huts (more people, but how many?); 500 men/ military kraal
Mention 1100 house/ 5500 man military estab. (Gardiner 1836: 206); 3 kraals -> 4000-5000 people estimated, probably less than 2000 each (Gardiner 1836: 70)]
kraals are “planned” what does this mean?; no “cities”
just storage huts & hen houses; isigodlo?
no burials except of important people – other thrown into the bush
see plate opposite Tyler (1891: 41); 10ft plus fence; stone walls around kraal (up-country) not around whole settlement (Krige 1936: 42)
no roads
had to swim – unskilled at this; special people lived near rivers to help people across
do not include all of the kings residences at which he stops?
Zulu village and architecture, circular in form (Krige 1936: 42); round thatched huts (Gibson 1903: 3)
no data ( ), see [traits] 33, 34; can a thatched hut be substantial?
no mention of division of interior space (except border on floor)
see above [trait 73]
each woman in a kraal has her own hut
floor made of clay & ant-heap; does this count as (+)?
unworked land reverts back to public ownership
private property [underlined] – no because land is not privately owned
Free access to unused land for grazing
(-) ?; not mentioned
livestock [underlined] – yes, some people have a lot of cattle, others don’t. But most who die wealthy run a kraal so they are polit. leaders
first feast at weddings? (Krige 1936: 122); (find ref. To king’s feasts); no use for wealth other than to support dependents (Gluckman 1940: 45)
no records
Mostly buried or burnt; really valuable things kept by relatives (Krige 1936: 162)
no writing, no mention of oral testament
shields by experts; for example, only some women are potters (Krige 1936: 208) and ironworking is also a spec. (Krige 1936: 210); see Krige (1936: 212) for experts in services & handicraft
significant [underlined]; primarily [underlined]; (no tourist trade until contact)
Full-time [underlined]; smith (Krige 1936: 209)
ear piercer (Krige 1936: 119); instructor of dance and song (Krige 1936: 135); stock castrator (Bryant 1965: 74)
Full-time [underlined] – how about an ear-piercer and headring saver - not necessarily full time, I’m afraid. (stock-castrator, skin dresser)
Experts at sewing on headrings (Krige 1936: 119); for list of professions (Bryant 1965: 74)
war captives forced to do this, also young boys (Krige 1936: 273); how about a butler (Bryant 1965: 61)
Shaka’s father had a cannibal chef
women brew beer
frequently [underlined]; brass rings
brass rings
does it count when cattle are lent out & their increase must be returned w/ them?
no mention of debts
no mention of this
each village practically self-sufficient, little… trade in the early days
for centuries… Arabs have traded along the east coast of Africa – beads thru Thonga, Delagoa Bay. Brass & copper rings from north
not sure what they traded, see Krige (1936: 213ff)
communal house building- food & drink as compensation. Poorer men attached to wealthy men for living; mostly social function
kings fields
men worked on kings fields, also local women
all men are artisans (Bryant 1965: 74); there weren’t too many artisans – no reference to “state smith”
junior warriors farm kings land. Based on kings wants (Krige 1936: 220); cattle to replace service requirements (Krige 1936: 221; Gluckman 1940: 34)
no
requirements followed kings whims
all taxes were "special” but not "in addition to regular taxes”
(what about vice versa); people living near the king offered service rather than goods
privately [underlined]; fields planted for the king by requirements. Also gifts of beer & etc. were always sent
no mention
(+); famine by distributing [underlined]
no mention
classificatory sib or clan, age grades (Krige 1936: 23); ascend. less prominent clansmen (Bryant 1965: 59)
Sib & age grade
I think there is a royal lineage clans
Kingly line known at least 3 generations (Krige 1936: 31); I think more was known how else could Bryant  trace it. See Bryant (1965: 32-35) for variance
sex and age are main determinants in relations
does hereditary smith-hood count?
exchange girl for cattle
just gifts (Krige 1936: 137-138)
Tyler (1891: 202) mentions housekeeping paraphernalia; feasts and gift exchange (Krige 1936: 122)
ceremonies not officiated
royal family - aristocracy
cattle brings prestige (Krige 1936: 185); cattle, as wealth, lead to social authority (Gibson 1903: 7); royal family - aristocracy (Gluckman 1940: 34ff)
Royal family vs. commoners
?; Royal high rank achieved – chiefs, military, distinct classes?; low rank (Gluckman 1940: 36)
?; the closer you are related to the ruler, the higher your status
liability [underlined]; [no mention of this]; men of rank allowed to sit w/ back to sun (Krige 1936: 231); men of rank could appeal to indunas directly (Krige 1936: 232)
rank class
Noble (?) rank [underlined]; certain ornaments are indications of rank
(-); no mention of this
there are no “categorically superior residencies”
I would think so. They use as much as they can. But the wealthy men would probably become political leaders
I think a man would have as many wives as he could support. But… (see [trait] 238 above)
servants [underlined] – not mentioned
right to be chief of kraal?; to be addressed & approached as noble (Gluckman 1940: 35); To face away from sun in trials (Gluckman 1940: 34-36); there are these rights or privilege?
dancing before battles [& to impress missionaries]
Hunt for dietary supplement, certain game belonged to the king by right… (they didn’t need it to subsist.)
?; deference to royal Zulus
status [underlined]; king & very important men are soldiers of note buried, others exposed [in the time of Shaka]
valuable things kept by relatives (Krige 1936: 162); not that much material wealth around, just cattle
no mention of this on Krige (1936: 192)
even the political leader doesn’t have an elaborate grave
I don’t think they had slaves at all
country divided into 13 parts, each ruled by an independent chief (Gibson 1903: 164)
King -> chiefs -> indunas -> (headmen); Zululand tribal areas wards communities (Gluckman 1940: 27, 39)
¼ – ½ milion
Unkunginglove; Gardiner 1836: 70 or before
population could redistribute itself to fall under fairer ruler
no, see Gluckman (1940: 42)
some man w/ a following sent to colonize uninhabited area.
sent to capital [underlined]; age sets sent for military training
king never actually tries a case. But decisions from appealed cases handed down in his name (sorcerers pardon case) (Gluckman 1940: 33)
can be appealed to; (sorcerer’s pardon case)
monarchy hereditary, but not first son of first wife
I have this impression but no ref.
required [underlined]; not necessary, but it helps (Gluckman 1940: 45); wealth does attract followers, therefore: political status
indep. Chiefs (Gibson 1903: 164)
kraal heads periodically responsible for attendance in chiefs council (national council) (Farrer 1879: 98); & king bound to consider advice from council (Gluckman 1940: 42)
2 chiefs indunas, judges who decide in king’s name
activities [underlined] – anything
centers  [striked out]
municipal [underlined]
secret agents [underlined] – spies of king
kings messengers; runners
but there is a general-in-chief
Great Induna
ministers [underlined] – no
it was punishable by death to impersonate the king’s messenger
may not [underlined]; see Bryant (1965: 74) in which earlier chief did engage in labor
slaves [striked out]
Laws & pronouncements
soldier who wants to get married (Krige 1936: 221); people come to solicit favors at law giving (Bryant 1965: 72)
Krige (1936: 221) mentions such a town which sounds like it recurs frequently
he collects cattle & needs people to herd them – he’d never travel alone anyway
no temples or church
chief slaughters animal for good of tribe (sacrifices) (Krige 1936: 87); First fruits (Krige 1936: 191)
(-); ?; oath [underlined]; British ceremony, for Cetyswayo – does this imply precedent? (Tyler 1891: 221)
objects from the ancestors (Gluckman 1940: 30); “king’s regalia” sacred soil -> tribal unity (Krige 1936: 243)
"all who came to live in Zululand had to aknowledge his (kings) sovereignty"
Gardiner (1836: 91) list titles
speaking evil of king -> death (Gardiner 1836: 95); capital punishment (Krige 1936: 224)
no gods
Clothes & possessions
strangle servants to accompany the king
(burial is secret) thorn bushes, stone lining…
originally dried out before burial. More recently wrapped in skin
graves of former kings visited
royal house "surpassing all others beauty & skill of construction"
personal [servant] attendants
steward and staff [underlined]; mention of butler (Bryant 1965: 61)
among others – hundreds
Tyler (1891: 45) refers to "harem" owner
night watchmen at royal kraal
leader [or state]; rulers[?] you count shields & arsegain? No!
the king handles foreign relations
in the case of murder or bodily injury, it is the chief who gets the fine; but if parties settle among themselves, the king never hears of it
in cases of sorcery & theft; maove poison
Zulus addicted to litigation
No record of land disputes
3 levels of court (by locality) but nature of offense is not the determinant (Krige 1936: 229); 3 judicial tribunals from kraal head to king (Farrer 1879: 98)
(+) ?; oath to ancestors required, swear truth
(good character references)
no penalty for false evidence
individual apprehension and detention [underlined]; “everyman is a policeman – nothing specialized” (Krige 1936: 223); junior official equivalent to policemen (Bryant 1965: 72)
king upheld customary law (Gluckman 1940: 33); sanctioned by “custom and traditionary record” (Gardiner 1836: 94)
new law created by king after case (Gluckman 1940: 33); runners announced projected laws among other things (Gluckman 1940: 38)
sorcery [underlined]; incest; rape punished by confiscations (forced gift) (Krige 1936: 228)
Theft
collective responsibility makes it necessary to report every wrong, lest you become responsible for it
(incest)?; incest (marriage to “sister”) carried death penalty.
(+); ?; the most fertile source of litigation… inheritance (Krige 1936: 229)
LESE majesty
no church
“A debt or action never lapses through length of time, for a descendant may be prosecuted for… his father. “ that is there is no time limit
designated agent [underlined]
ex. of incest
all goes to king or most of it, at least (Krige 1936: 222); Krige (1936: 228 footnote) says that part of murder fines go to the father of the victim
(-); ?; confiscation [underlined]; to king (Krige 1936: 224); Theft -> restitution & fine (Krige 1936: 229)
in case of homicide because “all blood belongs to the king” (Krige 1936: 228); fines for murder & property in case of death penalty (Krige 1936: 222)
inconclusive
from Gardiner Dingane’s brother
if a convicted sorcerer could get to the king safely, he was saved
soldiers could insult the king w/ impunity at first fruits (Krige 1936: 26); no pardon for crimes traditionally but ex. of pardon is given (Tyler 1891: 59)
in the case of incest
“expanding the kingdom into an empire” for the purpose of conquering other tribes
capture of cattle (Otterbein 1967: 354); main object: cattle (Gibson 1903: 23)
no religion really
most of the time they relied on surprise; pre- Chaka fights were pre-arranged (Gibson 1903: 8)

regularly leads the men [underlined]; one of the chief indunas had both political and military function; he was “commander in chief of a army” (Gluckman 1940: 33); see Krige (1936: 273) – “general” mentioned
“general-in-chief” next to king in rank (Farrer 1879: 112); he has other (advisory) function as well
see [traits] above?; second in command, 2 wing officers… but are they professional?
all able-bodied men w/ the possible exception of shamans (who later had to pay to get out)
core at capital-those of prime age; others could be called in from the periphery
militia [underlined]
called cowards and impaled; cowards made to suffer indignities
by shamans, later on
they received room and “board” (Krige 1936: 220); no wages, no rations (not much) (Bryant 1965: 78)
“royal salute” (Gibson 1903: 14); mention of “allegiance” & its transfer (Gibson 1903: 229); Konza making allegiance foreign troope ( Leslie 1875: 95)
by region requirements, companies (see [traits] above); Konza’d to Tshaka
subdivisions requirements into wings into companies (Farrer 1879: 112); every one of like age in local district (company) is part of requirement of every one of like age in Zululand
does dancing & “giya-ing” (imaginary battle jumps) count?; Yes (Gardiner 1836: 92); drilled for systematic attack under regimental commander (Gibson 1903: 13)
one short thrusting assegai
no horses
of boys & conquered warriors (Gibson 1903: 21); by prisoners of former wars (Farrer 1879: 112)
yes (Otterbein 1967: 351-355); hand to hand combat - thrust to kill at close range (Gibson 1903: 22)
“a close-order shield-to-shield formation w/ 2 ‘horns’…” (Otterbein 1967: 353); semi-circle (Krige 1936: 275)
see above trait
war like hunt, required co-operation; “Law of Chase” handed down (Gibson 1903: 9-10); formed rules for everything
weapons [underlined]; shields at chiefs kraal “shields and spears in custody of local head man”
“broad-bladed stabbing spear” (Otterbein 1967: 353); Shaka initiated thrusting rather than throwing (Krige 1936: 261)
identify military units [underlined] – head dress & color of shields identify units (Krige 1936: 262); color & pattern of shields (Tyler 1891: 212); novel fur or feather decoration (Bryant 1965: 78)
how about a war song?
to locate enemy (Krige 1936: 273); systematic espionage (Farrer 1879: 110)
swazi caves were sometimes besieged
forts [underlined] – military kraals 1000 men barracks (Gardiner 1836: 92);  barracks 800-900 men (Gardiner 1836: 28)
no mention of this
cattle
who will later carry baggage in military campaigns or fill ranks
King eats part of other king. This is not a general rule (Krige 1936: 246); Zulu are not cannibals (Farrer 1879: 114)
how about incorporated into baggage, carriers, etc. ? Used by Chaka in [unreadable]
brass arm bands; special decorations (Krige 1936: 263)
cattle (Krige 1936: 263); the two are connected though king was once reported to take all women
not really a nobility in the Aztec sense but war exploits did not bring high status
I think also before battle; men paraded in regiments (Gluckman 1940: 31)
definitely

allowed to live in peace but “watched over” (Gibson 1903: 16); Dingiswayo “had not greatly altered the tribal condition” (Gibson 1903: 18); Chaka – authority over small portional conquered land (Chaka did) (Gibson 1903: 25)

Ding. collected tribute but allowed the chiefs to continue ruling  (Gibson 1903: 18); check on example; conquered tribes incorporated (Krige 1936: 262); Tribes submitted in order to be allowed to live in peace (Gibson 1903: 16)
I think just tribute
a few kraals built in conquered territory (not overly many)
ancestors; Princess of Heaven
sacrifices to the ancestors (Krige 1936: 42); to secure their help (Gibson 1903: 56)
no active gods; no one prays to Unkulunkulu anyway (Callaway 1884: 8; "The religious system of the Amazulu")

?; no sense of after life or anything after death until after coming of the Christians - i can’t figure out where that came from; but life status carries over (Krige 1936: 284); + charact. (Farrer 1879: 133)
Question of whether they leave any meat. I think they do in some cases
blood, potions; spitting blood (Krige 1936: 257); “cleansing” in case of sickness, water sprinkled w/ leaves from bowl (Gardiner 1836: 95)
ancestors “asked to protect the inmates or thanked for blessings received”
only killed enemies and chief’s ritual cannibalism. Not sacrifice in religious sense
Kraal is temple so no shrines, idols or altars. Ancestors are personal however.
there are only “doctors” not priests, kraal heads are family priests
Priests [underlined] – headman is “priest” at sacrifices & ceremonies – represents ancestors & is responsible to & for his people
First fruits ceremony – King presides every year
religious specialists [underlined]; sacrifice cattle before battle
thank offering after battle successful, victorious
bury objects against wizards and lightning (Krige 1936: 47); sacrifice bullock to move ancestors from old to new kraal (Krige 1936: 53)
(+) ?; grave of chief is ‘a sacred spot’ – important sacrifices of national character made there
meat burned w/ incense at ear piercing ceremony
no writing
diviners [underlined]; (many references)
black earth
black earth
black earth
cooking, holding beer – I think milk pots – some ceramics but wood is preferred (Krige 1936: 208); they’re large (Krige 1936: 208); large pot for storing beer (Krige 1936: 396)
full-time [underlined] – ?; experts, skilled in the art; women
axes [underlined]
sewing [underlined]
furniture consists of mats and earthen pots
(not mats)
“Zulus never mined any other metals than iron” so I assume they must have mined that
used to smelt own iron (before contact) (Gibson 1903: 6)
furnace sink in hole…
did own smelting, not sure materials were indig. tho. (Gibson 1903: 6); they did mine iron (Gibson 1903: 46); from mts. (Gardiner 1836: 105)
probably not, see [trait] 552
“did not understand how to make brass”
moulds or pipes [not specialized enough]
check Robertson “Mission Life among the Zulu-Kafirs” (p. 279)
imported brass for ornaments
Copper & iron ornaments
baser metals; Brass ornaments
professional hereditary smiths
orig. unacquainted w/ canoes or water-life (Bryant 1965: 5); “rough-and-ready” boat, no oars, burned out planks lashed together maybe (Krige 1936: 215)
Krige says this is unclear. In Isaacs 224
no writing but some men developed excellent memories (Gibson 1903: 162); no letters (Bryant 1965: 36)
professional instructors of dance & song
schools [underlined]
how about if they can “describe” a perfect circle w/o cord?
specialists [underlined]; constellations observed for proper agricultural timing
I got the impression that life was pretty easy – no schedules
3 types mentioned; drums
no mentioned
teams compete at “stabbing the intsema” sort of a war-preparatory game for adolescent boys
Praise sayers/singers; professional instructors of dance & song (Krige 1936: 135); composers (Krige 1936: 339)
?; composers (Krige 1936: 339); but whole groups of people perform after training; soldiers (Krige 1936: 260); see teacher trait [#588]
beer
herbalist cures through efficacious plant preparations (Krige 1936: 298); Tyler (1965: 197) on medical art
